cards.back:
Av = -R2/R1

Negative sign = output is inverted relative to input.

cards.front: Which input receives the signal in an inverting amp?
cards.back:
Inverting input (-)

Signal goes through R1 to the (-) terminal.
Non-inverting (+) is grounded.

cards.front: What is the input impedance of an inverting amplifier?
cards.back:
Zin = R1

The virtual ground at the inverting node means the source 'sees' only R1.

cards.front: Activity 1 component values and expected gain?
cards.back:
R1 = 2.2kΩ, R2 = 39kΩ
Av = -39k/2.2k = -17.73

With 1Vpp input → 17.73Vpp output (inverted)

cards.front: What is 'virtual ground' in the inverting amplifier?
cards.back:
The inverting node (-) is at 0V

Because V+ = 0 (grounded) and V- = V+ (virtual short)
So V- = 0 even though it's not directly connected to ground.

cards.front: How to calculate maximum undistorted input?
cards.back:
Vi(max) = Vsat / |Av|

Example: If Vsat = 14V and Av = -20
Vi(max) = 14/20 = 0.7V

When calculated output > supply voltage

Output can't exceed approx. ±(Vsupply - 1V)
With ±15V supply, max output ≈ ±14V

cards.front: Key assumptions for deriving inverting amp gain?
cards.back:
1. No current into op-amp inputs (I- = 0)
2. Virtual short: V- = V+ = 0 (since V+ grounded)

These enable the KCL-based derivation.

Output is 180° out of phase with input

When input goes positive → output goes negative
When input goes negative → output goes positive

Zout ≈ 0 (very low)

Negative feedback keeps output impedance low regardless of op-amp's internal Zout.
